name.text: 37.1.3.2 Variance of a discrete probability distribution

questiontext.text:
The variance is usually written as \(\sigma^2\). For a frequency distribution it is:
\[\displaystyle{\sigma^2=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^n f_i(x_i-\mu)^2\qquad \text{where } \mu \text{ is the mean value}.}\] 
and can be expanded and ‘simplified’ to appear as:
\[\displaystyle{\sigma^2=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^n f_ix_i^2-\mu^2.}\] 
This is often quoted in words:

\(\qquad\)The variance is equal to the mean of the squares minus the square of the mean.

We now extend the concept of variance to a random variable.

Key Point

Let \(X\) be a random variable with values \(x_1,x_2,\ldots , x_n\). The variance of \(X\), which is written \(\text{V}(X)\) is defined by \[\text{V}(X)=\sum_{i=1}^n p_i(x_i-\mu)^2\] where \(\mu\equiv \text{E}(X)\). We note that \(\text{V}(X)\) can be written in the alternative form \[\text{V}(X)=\text{E}(X^2)-[\text{E}(X)]^2\] The standard deviation \(\sigma\) of a random variable is \(\sqrt{\text{V}(X)}\).
